main_text:
Three Controversies || Panpsychism
3.2 Panpsychism

Panpsychism is widely taken to provide a possible answer to the
mind-body problem and the by now (merely repetitive) reiteration of
Lotze’s commitment to panpsychism is easy to document. The fact that
Lotze said praiseworthy things about his former teacher, Fechner,
after the latter’s mental breakdown, is usually highlighted and we
are informed that “Lotze’s main criticism of Fechner is that
he is not bold enough … there were deeper metaphysical reasons
for thinking that all reality is alive” (Beiser, 2013, p. 235).
But this approach forces us to take Lotze’s equivocal statements at
face value when there are numerous clear indications that we should
not.

First of all, almost all of the quotations typically drawn from the
Mikrokosmus in support of panpsychism are actually phrased in
the form of questions (and not assertions), viz.

If we cannot account for the appearance of a mental state
[geistigen Zustandes] by those properties in virtue of which
we call matter matter, what hinders us from supposing that besides
those properties there is a store of inner life which usually escapes
our attention, and finds no other opportunity of manifestation than in
what we call mental life [geistiges Lebens]? (Micro,
I, p. 150)


Why, in opposition to matter as an ever dead substance, should all
mental activity [geistiges Regsamkeit] be condensed into the
special nature of a soul [Seele], destitute on its side of
the properties by means of which the physical elements make themselves
of account in Nature? (ibid.)


Might not the visible substance have directly a double life, appearing
outwardly as matter, and as such manifesting no property other than
those mechanical ones with which we are familiar, – internally
on the other hand moved mentally [geistig bewegt], aware of
the changes in its states, and accompanying with efforts the activity,
whose general subjection to law it is certainly not in its power
arbitrarily to alter? (ibid.)


Have things by their motions, while themselves destitute of enjoyment,
only to minister to souls [Seelen] as mere stimuli to this
mental life [innerlichen Leben]? (Micro, I, p. 353)


Has the one half of creation, that which we comprise under the name of
the material world, no function whatever save that of serving the
other half, the realm of mind [des Reiches des Geister], and
are we justified in longing to find the lustre of sense
[Sinnlichkeit] in that also whence we seem always to derive
it? (ibid.)


In the Mikrokosmus, Lotze emphasizes that panpsychism is
strongly motivated from the impetus to counter, in some fashion, the
excesses of materialism. But this very “justification,” he
comments, is simultaneously “the source of the barrenness of
this view” (Micro, I, p. 151): we don’t like
materialism, so we appeal to panpsychism, adopting the
counter-hypothesis that simply “ascribes to matter a secret
mental life” (ibid.). But why in the world ought we do that?

At best, panpsychism, under this pretext, is merely an empty and vain
idea, “a conception … that, [may be counted] among the
dreams of our imagination”; it names a belief about which the
most we may say is that it “may be one of those which do not
contradict actual facts” (Micro, I, p. 360). In a word, it
is possible, but scarcely probable and in no wise to be considered
actual. After all, were it quite literally to be true, then we would
have to adjust ourselves to the following curious state of affairs:
“Who could endure the thought that in the dust trodden by our
feet, in the prosaic texture of the cloth that forms our clothing, in
the materials shaped into all sorts of utensils … there is
everywhere present the fulness of animated life …?”
(Micro, I, p. 361). Who could truly inhabit such a ghastly
and ghostly realm?

Consequently, neither science nor philosophy has any need of such an
hypothesis, one that indeed bears an uncanny relation to mythological
thinking (remnants of which are still preserved in our culture,
through the influence of Greek art and thought). Nonetheless, whatever
its storied pedigree, “we … must not introduce it into
science.” From the sole requirements of knowledge alone,
“nothing remains for us but to gather from experience the laws
found valid in the ultimate ramifications of reality”
(Micro, I, p. 363). Among our philosophical inheritance from
German Romanticism, thus, cannot be counted “Schiller’s
Götter Griechenlands” (Micro, I, p. xiv) and
the like.

Nor can we, in any fashion, seek to derive this view from purely
self-interested metaphysical motives, viz.

The dislike to look on one part of the cosmos as but a blind and
lifeless instrument for the ends of another, the desire to diffuse
over all the joy of animation, and to vindicate a universe enjoying at
every point throughout its own existence a more perfect than one in
which a divided structure shows mentality [des Geistigen]
above an unconscious basis – in this we have but one series of
motives inviting us beneath the unruffled surface of matter behind the
rigid and regular repetitions of its workings, to seek the warmth of
mental activity [geistigen Regsamkeit] (Micro, I, p.
362).


In a word, fear of nihilism is also no justification. Indeed, at long
last, the only rationale that can be offered for the panpsychist
“wager” is purely aesthetic in nature: “nothing but
the beauty of the living form is made to us more intelligible by this
hypothesis” (Micro, I, p. 366). Indeed, in the end, we
may only admit that our scientific work “neither wants nor needs
panpsychism – rather, it is needed to satisfy the human spirit,
to make the nature of soul comprehensible” (Skrbina, 2007, p.
128).

At first glance, however, this explanation superficially suggests that
Lotze may be nothing more than a beautiful soul. Panpsychism must, at
bottom, be shown to possess some truly special significance, far
outstripping the utterly false assistance it would pretend to offer to
the natural sciences. For assisting the science of psychology, even
the very possibility of panpsychism is “wholly immaterial”
(Micro, I, p. 365). Rather, Lotze asserts, to be painfully
repetitive, that “nothing but the beauty of the living form
[die Schönheit der lebendigen Gestalt] is made to us more
intelligible by this hypothesis” (Micro, I, p. 366).
But what, precisely, could this gnomic utterance be taken to mean?

It appears that Lotze’s terminology cashes out directly as follows:
“The image which we now have to form of the living form [die
lebendige Gestalt] and its mental life is that of an association
of many beings” (Micro, I, p. 367). Lotze then extends
the figure by analogizing each human individual to our species
being:

All that we prize in life, and that is the source of nobler
enjoyments, rests on this mode of combination in a manifold; the human
race, embodies in countless individuals, leads the life of constant
reciprocal action, of mutual fellow-feeling in love and hatred, of
uninterrupted progress, that make all share in the gain of one part
(Micro, I, p. 368).


But this does not entail any submerging of the many into some one:
“The unity in which we long to be knit with another is always
completeness of intercourse, reciprocal enjoyment of what is without,
never the confused mingling in which all joy of union perishes”
(ibid.).

Consequently, as applied to each unique individual, we must admit that
ontogeny really does recapitulate phylogeny, by admitting that
“… its inner life never becomes ours and when the union
of different beings on which our living form [unsere lebendige
Gestalt] depends falls to pieces, while we shall all have gone
through something together, it will be as beings originally different
that after a passing contact again separate” (ibid.).

Panpsychism emerges hence as an aesthetic hypothesis that can be
called on to account for one thing and one thing only: the realization
forced earlier in the century by the French physiologists that life,
whatever it was, was a union of separate and quite heterogeneous
processes, held together in the most fragile of unions:

Bichat’s physiological conclusions grew primarily out of his
study of death, in which we identified death as a fragmented process,
consisting of the extinction of different organs and processes: the
death of locomotion, of respiration, of sense perceptions, of the
brain. If death was thus a multiple, dispersed event, then so was
organic life. According to Georges Canguilhem, “The genius of
Bichat was to decentralize the notion of life, to incarnate it in the
parts of organisms.” With Bichat begins the progressive
parcelization and division of the body into separate and specific
systems and functions that would occur in the first half of the
nineteenth century (Crary, 1992, pp. 78–79).


Each of us is then, quite literally, composed of others, who, while
coming together for a time, to work upon a common purpose, ultimately
disperse, returning to a more basic (and decomposed) form of
existence. That is the ultimate and, indeed, the only point of the
panpsychist perspective: we may view our individual being on analogy
with the cooperative workings of multiple entities, as in a larger
society. Society is simultaneously an image of the self, and vice
versa.

Now Lotze did his best to sugar coat this physiological revelation but
not, it seems, in order to make it more palatable; instead he wanted
to show, simultaneously, how little we have gained and how little we
have lost in its acknowledgement. In reality, the best gloss of
Lotze’s overarching strategy – as wrested from its original
point of reference – is that “… Lotze takes his
reader to the abyss only to pull him back and teach him a lesson. The
exercise in metaphysical brinkmanship is designed to show the reader
that the only salvation from nihilism, the only way forward in
metaphysics, lies in ethics …” (Beiser, 2013, p.
155).

Science has given and science has taken away. But, in reality, nothing
has changed. What matters is how we look at it. The nihilistic
conclusions of the natural sciences can’t change (or undermine
the truth of) human experience, no matter how deep our investigation
descends. Our situation is thus akin to that given admirable (if
somewhat dated meteorological) literary expression as follows:

A barometric low hung over the Atlantic. It moved eastward toward a
high-pressure area over Russia without as yet showing any inclination
to bypass this high in a northerly direction. The isotherms and
isotheres were functioning as they should. The air temperature was
appropriate relative to the annual mean temperature and to the
aperiodic monthly fluctuations of the temperature. The rising and
setting of the sun, the moon, the phases of the moon, of Venus, of the
rings of Saturn, and many other significant phenomena were all in
accordance with the forecasts in the astronomical yearbooks. The water
vapor in the air was at its maximal state of tension, while the
humidity was minimal. In a word that characterizes the facts fairly
accurately, even if it is a bit old-fashioned: It was a fine day in
August 1913 (Musil 1930–1945 [1965], p. 3).


The poetic and the evaluative may appear resolutely old-fashioned in a
cold, utilitarian universe. But it names precisely an impulse of human
knowers that can never be replaced, supplanted or repressed.
Practically speaking, we are value-finding beings. We will continue to
utter such strange and human constructions as “the sun is coming
up” or “it was a very fine day,” for our world is both poetry
and prose. And it can never be simply one or the other for human
existence.
